title: 113_hr4496
content: The Act titled "Covering People With Pre-Existing Conditions Act of 2014" establishes universal access programs to improve high-risk pools and reinsurance markets for individuals with pre-existing conditions. Each State must operate a qualified State reinsurance program or a qualifying State high-risk pool by January 1, 2015, funded by State premium assessments. Each State must operate a qualified State reinsurance program or a qualifying State high-risk pool by January 1, 2015, funded by State premium assessments. Subject to certain conditions, State funds equivalent to the portion derived from State premium assessments not used on State health care programs must be applied to the operation of the program. States not operating a qualified high risk pool as of the enactment of this Act have specific requirements to meet. States not operating a qualified high-risk pool must establish a qualified State reinsurance program by the enactment of this Act. The State must establish a qualified State reinsurance program by the enactment of this Act, and if a State is already operating a qualified high-risk pool, it will be treated as such for the purposes of the Public Health Service Act. As of January 1, 2015, a State operating a qualified high-risk pool must meet certain criteria to be considered as such under the Public Health Service Act. The State can utilize premium assessment funds for this purpose. The State may use premium assessment funds to transition from a high-risk pool to a qualified State reinsurance program if the pool is in strong fiscal health. If the State's high-risk pool is financially stable, it can use premium assessment funds to transition to a qualified State reinsurance program for small group health insurance coverage. A qualified State reinsurance program for small group health insurance coverage can be operated by a State program in accordance with established models. It may provide reinsurance on a prospective or retrospective basis to protect health insurance issuers against annual aggregate spending. A qualified State reinsurance program may provide reinsurance on a prospective or retrospective basis to protect health insurance issuers against annual aggregate spending and individual catastrophic costs. It satisfies HIPAA requirements and is deemed a qualified high-risk pool under the Public Health Service Act. A qualifying State high risk pool must offer two coverage options, including a high deductible health plan with a health savings account, and have stable funding. The high risk pool must offer two coverage options, including a high deductible health plan with a health savings account, have stable funding, eliminate waiting lists, and cover individuals after the 24-month disability waiting period. The high risk pool must allow coverage for individuals who would be eligible for Medicare after the 24-month disability waiting period, limit premiums to 150 percent of the average standard risk rates, and conduct education and outreach activities. The high-risk pool must provide coverage for individuals eligible for Medicare after the 24-month disability waiting period, limit premiums to 150 percent of average rates, conduct education and outreach, and offer preventive services for chronic diseases. Verification of citizenship or alien qualification is required. The high-risk pool must cover preventive services and disease management for chronic diseases. Only citizens and nationals of the United States are eligible to participate in a qualifying State high-risk pool receiving funds under the Public Health Service Act. As a condition of receiving funds under the Public Health Service Act, States must certify that applicants for coverage in high-risk pools provide documentation of citizenship or nationality. The Secretary will maintain necessary records. To receive funds under the Public Health Service Act, States must certify that high-risk pool applicants provide documentation of citizenship or nationality. The Secretary will maintain records for determining citizenship or nationality only once per individual. Starting January 1, 2015, a pool must be a qualifying State high-risk pool to be eligible under section 2745. As of January 1, 2015, a pool must be a qualifying State high-risk pool to qualify under section 2745 of the Public Health Service Act. The Secretary has the authority to waive requirements for State reinsurance programs and high-risk pools. Additional funding is appropriated for carrying out section 2745. In addition to any other amounts appropriated, $15 billion is allocated for fiscal years 2015 through 2024, and an extra $10 billion for fiscal years 2020 through 2024 for section 2745 of the Public Health Service Act. Definitions for "health insurance coverage" and "health insurance issuer" are provided in this section. In this section, definitions are provided for "health insurance coverage" and "health insurance issuer" as per section 2791 of the Public Health Service Act. The term "current section 2745 qualified high risk pool" is defined as per section 2745(g) of the Public Health Service Act. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The curr_chunk defines the term "standard risk rate" as a rate determined under the State high risk pool by considering premium rates charged by other health insurance issuers and established using actuarial techniques. The term "State" refers to any of the 50 States or the District of Columbia.
